label: Timer
info:
Periodically send time-based event messages which are used to trigger
automation.

# Details

This flow divides each day into five segments. It sends a message
with `msg.topic` set to `trigger` at the start of each
segment<sup>*</sup>. It periodically sends such `trigger` messages via
a `link out` node to flows on the _Shades_ and _Lighting_ tabs. Each
such message has `msg.payload` set to an object with the following
properties:

| Property               | Description                                                                             |
|------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| `msg.payload.lighting` | Boolean value indicating whether or not lighting automation is currently enabled        |
| `msg.payload.shades`   | Boolean value indicating whether or not window covering automation is currently enabled |
| `msg.payload.theme`    | String indicating which lighting theme to activate in the evening                       |
| `msg.payload.time`     | String indicating which the current time of day                                         |

> <sup>*</sup>The wording here describes the canonical case of exactly
> five `trigger` events per day. In reality, more or fewer than five
> `trigger`  events may be sent in a given day depending on when and
> how often flows are restarted as well as corner cases as to how
> certain segments are defined, as described below.

### Time

The `msg.payload.time` for each `trigger` message will be one of the
following following strings:

| `msg.payload.time` | Description<sup>**</sup>                                                                                    |
|--------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| `morning`          | Sent at sunrise                                                                                             |
| `midday`           | Sent when the sun is high enough to no longer be shining directly into east-facing windows                  |
| `afternoon`        | Sent when the sun is coming from the west and low enough to start shining directly into west-facing windows |
| `evening`          | Sent at sunset                                                                                              |
| `night`            | Sent at bedtime, as described below                                                                         |

> <sup>**</sup>The sun's position is obtained each minute using
> [suncalc](https://www.npmjs.com/package/suncalc). "Coming
> from the west" means the sun's azimuth is greater than 0, otherwise
> it is coming from the east. The sun being "low enough" to shine
> directly into windows is determined empirically for a given house
> by comparing the sun's altitude as reported by _suncalc_ at various
> times of day to how the sunlight is or is not intruding
> uncomfortably at that moment.

Canonically, `trigger` events are sent five times per day at the times
specified in the preceding table, including times that vary from day
to day due to randomly generated offsets or the changing position of
the sun over the course of a year. That said, "extra" `trigger`
messages will be sent when flows are restarted or when the user takes
certain actions using dashboard controls such as changing the bedtime
or enabling or disabling lighting and window shade automation.
Similarly, some `trigger` messages may be missing or skipped on any
given day. For example, the criteria defining `midday` are never met at
certain times of year for some latitudes.

More precisely, a new `trigger` event is sent:

1. When flows are started
2. When a new value for `sunrise`, `sunset`, `bedtime` or `theme` is
   calculated each day or, in the case of `bedtime`, a user changes
   the _Bedtime_ setting on the dashboard
3. A state transition is detected when handling a `now` message each
   minute, using the logic implied by the preceding table
4. Lighting or window shade automation is enabled or disabled via the
   dashboard, as described in the documentation for their respective
   flow tabs

In summary, the values for `sunrise`, `sunrise` and `bedtime` are
calculated once whenever flows start up and again at the start of each
day. The value for `bedtime` is recalculated any time a user changes
the _Bedtime_ setting on the dashboard. The `bedtime` calculation
includes an offset that is randomly calculated each day, as described
below. In addition, `now` events are sent each minute and their handler
compares the current time to the rules described above in order to
decide when to send `trigger` event messages and what their payloads
should contain.

#### Bedtime

A user can choose a value for "bedtime" from a dropdown control on the
dashboard. The actual time at which an event with `msg.topic` set to
`trigger` and `msg.payload.time` set to `night` will vary slightly each
day. The intent is to provide a modest degree of simulated presence when
the home is unoccupied. In particular, this flow sets the value of
`msg.payload.time` in `trigger` event messages by adding or subtrating
a randomly generated offset of up 30 minutes to the hour specified by
the _Bedtime_ dashboard control. The offset is regenerated once each
day and also when a user changes any of the dashboard settings
controlling automation.

#### Midday and Afternoon

At first glance, dividing each day into five distinct time ranges may
seem excessive. However, different types of home automation rules
focus on distinct criteria. The `midday` and `afternoon` values for
`msg.payload.time` in `trigger` event messages are used to control
east- and west-facing window coverings in addition to the `morning`,
`evening` and `night` values which are also of interest for lighting.
See the documentation for the _Shades_ and _Lighting_ flow tabs for
more information on how the various values for `msg.payload.time` are
used.

### Theme

The `msg.payload.theme` property of `trigger` event messages is used to
indicate special times of year when specific lighting schemes might be
appropriate:

| `msg.payload.theme` | Description                      |
|---------------------|----------------------------------|
| `tribal`            | July 1 - 4 (US Independence Day) |
| `spooky`            | Any day in October               |
| `jolly`             | Any day in December              |
| `standard`          | Any other day                    |

Display a message as a "toast" on the

name: Hue API V2
info:
This subflow encapsulates logic necessary to subscribe to event messages
sent by a Philips Hue Bridge. It wraps this fairly complex logic as a
subflow as a convenience for connecting to multiple bridges on a single
LAN.

# Input

The receipt of any input message triggers a sequence of events as
described below. The actual content of the incoming message is ignored.

# Output

An ongoing stream of event messages wrapped in a data structure suitable
for providing a set of dynamically created dashboard controls using a
`ui_template` node.

# Details

This subflow requires the following configuration:

| Environment Variable | Description                                                                       |
|----------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| `ADDRESS`            | IP address or host name of the Hue bridge                                         |
| `KEY`                | A valid client application key for the Hue bridge                                 |
| `TARGET`             | The label of a `link in` node that will be called to send messages to the Hue bridge |
| `BRIDGE`             | A unique name for the Hue bridge at the given `ADDRESS`                           |

See
<https://developers.meethue.com/develop/application-design-guidance/hue-bridge-discovery/>
for information on determining the value for `${ADDRESS}`.

See <https://developers.meethue.com/develop/hue-api-v2/getting-started/>
for information on how to generate the value for `${KEY}`; the
_@parasaurolophus/node-red-create-hue-application-key_ subflow provides
a convenience wrapper for the relevant API.

The value of `${TARGET}` must be the name of a `link in` node that
connects to an instance of the
_@parasaurolophus/node-red-send-hue-command_ subflow configured
with the same values for `${ADDRESS}` and `${KEY}`. The output of that
subflow must connect to a `link out` node configured to return its
caller.

The value of `${BRIDGE}` can be any string you wish to identify a
particular bridge. It will be used to form flow context storage keys.

Upon receipt of any incoming message, this subflow:

1. Fetches the complete set of "resources" from the Hue bridge
2. Parses and reformats a subset of that metadata for use in
   dynamically creating dashboard controls for the light groups and
   scenes defined using the native Hue mobile app
3. Uses a
   [@parasaurolophus/node-red-eventsource](https://flows.nodered.org/node/@parasaurolophus/node-red-eventsource)
   node to subscribe to event messages sent by the bridge
4. Sends update messages each time the state of the dynamically created
   dashboard controls change

The output of this flow should be connected to a `ui_template` node. The
output of that `ui_template` should be sent to an instance of the
_@parasaurolophus/node-red-send-hue-command_ subflow configured with the
same values for `${ADDRESS}` and `${KEY}`. Typically, this would be
through a `link call` node configured to invoke the same `link in` as
specified by `${TARGET}`.

meta.author: parasaurolophus <apps@rader.us>
meta.desc: Wrap the API (V2) exposed by a Philips Hue Bridge

name: Send Hue Command
info:
Send a HTTP request to the API (V2) on a Philips Hue Bridge.

# Input

See the documentation for the `http request` node for information about
how to format a message for use with an HTTP based API like that exposed
by a Hue Bridge. In particular, this subflow assumes that `msg.payload`
and `msg.method` will be set appropriately for the particular API entry
point you wish to invoke. In addition, this subflow assumes that
`msg.topic` is the bridge resource URI representing the command entry
point or resource to fetch. It will be converted to a proper value for
the `msg.url` property, as described below.

# Output

The the output of a `http request` node used to interact with the Hue
bridge.

# Details

This subflow will set `msg.url` and `msg.headers` according to the
values of:

- `msg.topic`
- `${ADDRESS}`
- `${KEY}`

before sending the message through to a `http request` node. The URL
will be formed by prepending the `htts://` scheme and value of the
`${ADDRESS}` environment variable to `msg.topic`. The value of
`msg.headers` will include the client application security token
contained in the `${KEY}` environment variable. The other message
properties will be passed through unchanged to the `http request` node.

See <https://developers.meethue.com/develop/hue-api-v2/> for details of
the various API entry points that can be invoked using this subflow.

See
<https://developers.meethue.com/develop/application-design-guidance/hue-bridge-discovery/>
for information on how to obtain the `${ADDRESS}` for your bridge.

See <https://developers.meethue.com/develop/hue-api-v2/getting-started/> for
information on how to generate a value to pass as the `${KEY}`. The
_@parasaurolophus/node-red-create-hue-application-key_ subflow provides
a convenient way to invoke the relevat API entry point.

meta.author: parasaurolophus <apps@rader.us>
meta.desc: Send a message to the Philips Hue Bridge API V2

name: parse metadata
info:
Reformat the resource data received from the Hue bridge for more
efficient access while processing server-sent events and dynamically
managing dashboard controls. Store the reformatted data in flow
context. "Prime the pump" for server-sent event handling.

# Input

Response from a Hue bridge containing response to a `/resource` request.

# Outputs

1. A stream of `grouped_light` events in the same format that would
   be received as server-sent events
2. A message used to signal that the flow context is ready to start
   receiving event messages sent by the Hue bridge.

# Details

Use the value of `${BRIDGE}` as a key to store this subflow instance's
data in flow context as `$parent.hue.${BRIDGE}`.

Subscribe to server-sent events from the
[Hue Bridge API v2](https://developers.meethue.com/develop/hue-api-v2/).

See
<https://developers.meethue.com/develop/hue-api-v2/core-concepts/#events>
for more information.

Set `msg.payload` to the URL and `initDict` parameters required by the
[Hue Bridge API V2](https://developers.meethue.com/develop/hue-api-v2/)

See
<https://developers.meethue.com/develop/hue-api-v2/core-concepts/#events>
for more information.

info: Set `msg.payload` to `msg.payload.data`.

Split the array in `msg.payload` into individual messages.

Split the array in `msg.payload` into individual messages.

name: daily
info: Send the current timestamp every morning at 1AM

name: sun
info:
Use [suncalc](https://www.npmjs.com/package/suncalc) to determine the
timestamps for sunrise and sunset.

# Input

- `msg.payload.time` contains a timestamp

# Output

- `msg.payload.sunrise` is the timestamp for sunrise reported by
  _suncalc_
- `msg.payload.sunset` is the timestamp for sunset reported by
  _suncalc_

# Details

This function requires permission to load the _suncalc_ package and
that environment variables named `LATITUDE` and `LONGITUDE` specify the
geographical coordinates to use when calling `suncalc.getTimes()`.

name: bedtime
info:
# Input

`msg.payload.time` contains a timestamp

# Output

`msg.payload.bedtime` set to a randomly generated timestamp

# Details

The timestamp in `msg.payload.bedtime` is the result of adding a
randomly generated offset of plus or minus 30 minutes to the hour
specified by the `bedtime` flow context variable on the same day as that
specified by `msg.payload.time`. This requires a filesystem-backed
context store named `file` and assumes that the `bedtime` context
variable will have been set by a dashboard control. It uses a default
value of 22 (10PM) if `bedtime` has not yet been set.

name: theme
info:
# Input

`msg.payload.time` contains a timestamp

# Output

`msg.payload.theme` set to one of the following strings:

| Payload    | Description         |
|------------|---------------------|
| `tribal`   | July 1 - 4          |
| `spooky`   | Any day in October  |
| `jolly`    | Any day in December |
| `standard` | Any other day       |

# Details

The date which determines `msg.payload.theme` is that specified by the
timestamp in `msg.payload.time`.

name: send daily
info: // nrlint align-to-grid:off

name: every minute
info: Send the current timestamp every minute.

func: rbe
info: Block for each topic unless the payload changes.

name: assumes that a filesystem-backed context store exists named 'file'

label: Bedtime
info:
Dashboard dropdown allowing users to select a value to
use when calculating each day's bedtime.

name: at start
info: Send the current timestamp when the flow starts.

name: get flow.bedtime
func:
msg.topic = 'bedtime'
msg.payload = flow.get('bedtime', 'file') || 22

node.status({
    text: msg.payload,
    shape: 'dot',
    fill: 'blue'
})

return msg
info:
Set `msg.payload` to the value of `flow.bedtime` using the context
store named `file` or to the number 22 (denoting 10PM) if
`flow.bedtime` is undefined.

info: // nrlint align-to-grid:off

Set `flow.bedtime` to `msg.payload` using the context store named
`file`.

name: millis
info:
Set `msg.topic` to `daily`.

Set `msg.payload` to `{"time":timestamp}` where _timestamp_ is the
current time as reported by the `$millis()` JSONata function.

label: Refresh
info:
Trigger the dynamic creation of dashboard controls by querying the
Hue and PowerView API's at start up and each time the _Refresh_
button is pressed.

Wait for the first two messages to arrive. Send a combined payload for
both messages and again each time a new input value arrives.

name: time
info:
Use [suncalc](https://www.npmjs.com/package/suncalc) to send a message
containing a string denoting the current time of day.

# Input

- `msg.payload.now` contains the current timestamp
- `msg.payload.daily` contains on object with `sunrise`, `sunset`,
  `bedtime` and `theme` properties, as described below.

# Outputs

- `msg.topic` is `time`
- `msg.payload` is an object with the following properties:

  | Property               | Description                                   |
  |------------------------|-----------------------------------------------|
  | `msg.payload.lighting` | Value of the `lighting` flow context variable |
  | `msg.payload.shades`   | Value of the `shades` flow context variable   |
  | `msg.payload.theme`    | Passed through from the input                 |
  | `msg.payload.time`     | One of the `time` strings described below     |

# Details

This function requires permission to load the _suncalc_ package and
that environment variables named `LATITUDE` and `LONGITUDE` specify the
geographical coordinates to use when calling `suncalc.getPosition()`.

It uses the values of `msg.payload.now`, `msg.payload.daily.sunrise`,
`msg.payload.daily.sunset` and `msg.payload.daily.bedtime` in the
input to set `msg.payload.time` to one of the following values in
in the output:

| `msg.payload.time` | Description                                                                                              |
|--------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| `morning`          | Starts at sunrise; ends when the sun is coming from the east and risen above a particular alitude        |
| `midday`           | Starts when the sun has reached a particular altitude; ends when the sun has dropped below that altitude |
| `afternoon`        | Starts when the sun is coming from the west and is below a particular altitude                           |
| `evening`          | Starts at sunset; ends at bedtime                                                                        |
| `night`            | Starts at bedtime; ends at sunrise the next day                                                          |

name: update shades dashboard
info: // nrlint align-to-grid:off

store named `file` or to `false` if `flow.lighting` is undefined.

Send Basement Hue Command
info: Send rate-limited messages to the _Basement_ Hue bridge.
Display error messages on the dashboard and in the debug pane.

name: assumes ${BASEMENT_HUE_ADDRESS} and ${BASEMENT_HUE_KEY} are defined for the flow
Basement Hue
info: Subscribe to server-sent events from the _Basement_ Hue bridge.

name: Basement Hue Controls
info:
Display dynamically created dashboard controls for the _Basement_
Hue bridge.

_Basement_ Hue bridge.

name: ${ADDRESS}, ${KEY}, ${BRIDGE} and ${TARGET} are set by this group
basement hue status
info: Monitor `EventSource.readyState` for the _Basement_ Hue bridge.

name: locale strings
info:
Replace `msg.payload` by recursively walking input value, substituting
`Date.toLocaleString()` wherever a `Date` object or an integer is
detected.

This only works if all integers in `msg.payload` are, in fact,
timestamps that should be displayed to the user as dates.

name: stringify
func:
msg.now = new Date().toLocaleString()
msg.payload = JSON.stringify(msg.payload, undefined, 1)
return msg
info:
Pretty-print `msg.payload` and add the current date and time as
`msg.now`.
